questions.text: For eradication/control of measles, immunization coverage should be at least
questions.explanation: Measles has an R0 around 12–18, so herd-immunity thresholds are high. Programs generally aim for ≥95% coverage (≈96% in options) to interrupt transmission.

questions.text: Period of maximum infectivity in mumps is during
questions.explanation: Mumps is most infectious from ~2 days before to ~5 days after parotitis; peak transmissibility is just before/around onset (prodromal/early swelling).

questions.text: Major epidemics of influenza A occur at intervals of
questions.explanation: Seasonal influenza A shows larger epidemic waves every ~2–3 years due to antigenic drift; pandemics (antigenic shift) are far less frequent.

questions.text: The most common source of infection for diphtheria is a
questions.explanation: Although cases and subclinical infections transmit, chronic carriers are the most important reservoir and commonest source in the community.

questions.text: Schick test is done in
questions.explanation: The Schick test assesses susceptibility to diphtheria toxin (i.e., lack of antitoxin). It is not a test for meningitis, pertussis, or polio.

questions.text: Adjuvant present in DPT vaccine is
questions.explanation: DPT is an alum-adsorbed vaccine. Depending on formulation, aluminium phosphate or aluminium hydroxide may be used; many programs specify aluminium phosphate.

questions.text: Recommended site of administration of DPT in infants is
questions.explanation: Give IM in the anterolateral aspect of the thigh (vastus lateralis) in infants. Avoid gluteal site due to variable fat/nerve injury risk.

questions.text: The most severe complications following DPT are due to …….. component
questions.explanation: Whole-cell pertussis component is associated with fever/rare neurological AEFIs. (Acellular pertussis has fewer reactions but is costlier.)

questions.text: The vaccine usually given to pilgrims to the Middle East is
questions.explanation: Hajj/Umrah pilgrims require quadrivalent meningococcal (ACWY) vaccination as per Saudi regulations.

questions.text: Best index to estimate case load of T.B. in a community is
questions.explanation: ‘Case load’ refers to the number of existing patients needing care—best reflected by prevalence of disease (not infection).

questions.text: Prevalence of T.B. infection in a community is estimated by
questions.explanation: Tuberculin skin testing (TST) estimates infection prevalence at the population level; microscopy/culture/X-ray reflect disease.

questions.text: The amount of PPD used in Mantoux test in India is
questions.explanation: India commonly uses 1 TU PPD RT23 with Tween 80 intradermally for Mantoux testing.

questions.text: Result of Mantoux test is read after
questions.explanation: Induration is read at 48–72 hours; if a single option must be chosen, 48 hours is commonly accepted in many MCQs.

questions.text: Present day BCG vaccine is supplied as
questions.explanation: BCG is supplied as a lyophilized (freeze-dried) vaccine that must be reconstituted with the correct diluent.

questions.text: The diluent used for reconstituting BCG vaccine is
questions.explanation: Use the manufacturer-provided normal saline diluent (not distilled water/dextrose) to ensure correct pH and stability.

questions.text: Reconstituted BCG vaccine should be used within
questions.explanation: After reconstitution, BCG potency falls quickly; use within 6 hours (discard remaining).

questions.text: The age for BCG vaccination is recommended at
questions.explanation: BCG is ideally given at birth (or at the earliest contact if missed). Programs also accept early infancy as catch-up.

questions.text: At the village level sputum for AFB is collected and fixed by
questions.explanation: Under field protocols, the multi-purpose male health worker typically handles sputum collection/fixation for microscopy.

questions.text: Source of most polio infections are
questions.explanation: Most poliovirus transmission arises from asymptomatic/subclinical infections and carriers, not just recognized paralytic cases.

questions.text: Risk factors for development of paralytic polio include
questions.explanation: ‘Provocation’ polio has been associated with recent intramuscular injections; tonsillectomy relates to bulbar risk; hence all of the above.
